bio: Chef Antonio Diaz was born and raised in Naples, Italy, where he grew up surrounded by the sights, sounds, and flavors of Italian cuisine. From an early age, Luigi was fascinated by the art of cooking, and he spent countless hours in his family's kitchen, watching his mother and grandmother prepare traditional Italian dishes

ingredients: Salt and black pepper to taste
cookingMethod: Cook the spaghetti according to package instructions.
While the spaghetti is cooking, cook the pancetta in a large skillet over medium heat until crispy. Add the garlic and cook for another minute.
In a bowl, beat the eggs and mix in the grated cheese, salt, and black pepper.
When the spaghetti is cooked, reserve 1 cup of the pasta water and drain the rest. Add the spaghetti to the skillet with the pancetta and garlic, and toss to coat.

Remove the skillet from the heat and pour in the egg mixture, stirring quickly to coat the spaghetti. The residual heat will cook the eggs and create a creamy sauce. If the sauce is too thick, add a little bit of the reserved pasta water to loosen it.
Garnish with chopped parsley and serve hot.

ingredients: Salt and black pepper to taste
cookingMethod: In a large skillet, heat the butter over medium heat. Add the beef and cook until browned on all sides. Remove the beef from the skillet and set aside.
In the same skillet, add the onion and garlic and cook until softened, about 2-3 minutes. Add the mushrooms and cook until they release their moisture and start to brown, about 5-7 minutes.
Sprinkle the flour over the vegetables and stir to combine. Slowly pour in the beef broth, stirring constantly, until the sauce thickens. Add the cooked beef back to the skillet and stir to combine.
Remove the skillet from the heat and stir in the sour cream. Season with salt and black pepper to taste.
Garnish with chopped parsley and serve hot over egg noodles, rice, or mashed potatoes.
